Thomas Ellis was elected president
of the Freshman Class in the final
elections held last Friday in Latrobe
Hall. The other officers of the class
elected at that time are Melville
Locker, vice-president; Marvin Kolker, secretary; Allan Pinkerton,
treasurer; Stanley Prager, sergeantat-arms; and Everett Gaunt, Student
Council representative.
These results were announced by
members of the Student Council after
the final elections, previous to which
there had been held nominations and
primary elections on Wednesday and
Thursday, to narrow down the extremely large field of candidates.

It all started when several St.
John's boys came over to Baltimore
and proceeded to paint the town red
with particular reference to the Hopkins campus. The police department,
however, always on the job, caught
them red-handed, and they were arrested, duly tried, and sentenced to
clean the paint that they had splattered all over the place.
They cleaned the campus, and went
back to Annapolis, but they were
highly indignant—so would you be in
their predicament—so when Benjamin Arnstein sallied forth from the
dorms to mail a letter, he disappeared in thin air.

Business Student
The only Business Economics student to be elected to an office is
Prager, who hails from New York.
He is a candidate for the Barnstormers and has been cast in their forthcoming production. He is also a Phi
Alpha pledgee.
From far-off Indiana comes Everett Gaunt, who is enrolled in the College of Arts and Sciences.
Both Ellis and Gaunt have come
to the Hopkins holders of scholarships.

Frosh Commission
Discuss Fraternities
Two lively discussions, one on the
personal experiences of members with
regard to fraternities and the other
concerning the effects of alcoholic
beverage, featured last Thursday's
meeting of the Freshman Commission. The meeting was held at 6 p. m.
in Levering Hall.
Supper for the
members preceded the discussions.
To become a member of the Commission, the purpose of which is to
discuss freshman affairs, one must
be nominated by a regular member.
The three officers carefully consider
him, and if they find him acceptable,
he is placed on the roll.

Students Battle Policemen
With Tear Gas Bombs;
Firemen Put Out Bonfire
Tear gas bombs, flat tires on a police car, a light skirmish between
firemen and students, a stolen lantern;
all this was the result of the greatest display of "school spirit" shown
at the Johns Hopkins in a long time,
Although the night was Junior Rally night, the entire affair was dominated by the freshmen. The original
plan of the juniors was to make a
bonfire to arouse spirit for the JayJohnny game.
The students ransacked the stadium, the woods, and
alleys near the school to procure the
wood for the fire. The policemen let
the students build the fire, and it
roared at a merry rate.
All was peaceful and serene, but

The Last Luncheon?
WORD HAS reached us that the International Relations Club is wallowing in the depths of insecurity this
years as the direct result of an unprecedented penury
of members. The club is viewing the future with uncertainty, our outpost reports, and has decided to disband
unless a sharp pick-up is immediately effected within
its ranks. For this reason it has designated tomorrow's
luncheon meeting as the critical point in the determination of its continued existence. A satisfactory attendance
will enable it to persist and perhaps push forward; a
poor turn-out is to be considered indicative of lack of
student interest and will in all probability suffice for the
group's immediate and voluntary demise.
We are interested in the fate of this particular organization because it offers convincing evidence to a theory
which we have long held. This theory concerns those
students who actively scorn and score liberal and radical campus groups even to the point of egg baths, all
the while professing their preference and loyalty to the
status quo.
Yet, do they support that club which is peculiarly
ideal for their beliefs—namely, the conservative Relations Club, which is merely an informative discussion
group and takes no definite stand on current questions?
They do not, and, by that very token, denote that they
are not particularly interested or that they know all
about it already. The second inference is extremely
hazardous; the first allows just the least bit of suspicion to creep in concerning their real reason for perpetrating the disgrace of last April.
The Relations Club is prepared to give this conservative element a well-grounded basis on which to rest its
pretensions, so that it may counter with packs of facts
rather than lack of tact to the arguments advanced by
those with more radical leanings. This is the purpose
of its existence, and, as such, we heartily urge a good
measure of support at tomorrow's luncheon.

Religious Martyr--1934 Model
THIS Dr. Lynn Harold Hough is certainly a glutton for
punishment, make no mistake about that! If you question
the authority or authenticity of this statement, the
following explanation should swing you over:
Dr. Hough was one of the guests and principal speakers at the "Y" conference held at Eagles Mere last summer. Now Eagles Mere is a beautiful place, conducive
to practically every conceivable comfort. Dr. Hough
must have accepted the invitation to attend firm in the
conviction that he would lecture ever so occasionally
between hikes and blissful slumber. Or perhaps he contemplated writing another book 'neath the sylvan
friendliness of the environs.
Poor man, little did he reckon with a bunch of inquisitive imps who hailed from the Hopkins and who
evidently were crusading adherents of Veritas vos liberabit. For from the moment of his arrival to the time
when he tottered from the scene of action a sadder, yet
wider, clergyman, he was constantly pestered, peppered,
and finally sequestered by the murderous barrage of
questions put to him by these pitiless, insolent scamps.
The editor recalls one night in particular when he and
several others inveigled Dr. Hough into their room at
9.30 p. m. and hammered away until it was mutually
agreed to interrupt at 2 o'clock in conformity with an
alleged NRA code for religion!!
Don't think for a moment, however, that Dr. Hough
was revealed to disadvantage in these midsummer nightmares. If we had been unable to gain any satisfaction
from him at the outset, we would have dropped him
without further ado—we're quite independent, as you
notice. But the very nature of his replies led us on
ever gradually to follow him in his line of religious reasoning. At times we were forced to disagree violently,
upon other occasions we demurred; yet our impression
of the man was in no wise lessened by these frequent
clashes of opposing beliefs.
And so this week he has returned as guest of the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A. upon the occasion of its golden anniversary. He is to speak at tonight's Supper Club and
will also address the assembly on Thursday. But between these two public appearances, we can't censure
him if he goes into hibernation—experience should have
taught him that he can expect to find little Christian

Now as to Washington's way of thinking, on the basis
of the facts it has, concerning the probabilities in East
Asia, that vast testing-ground of the multitudinous nonaggressive Chinese, the restless, warm-water-seeking
Slays, and the short, sturdy, dour, death-scorning, expanding Japanese. There, too, barring the chapter of
accidents, Washington regards peace as at least temporarily more likely than war. The Nanking Government
is considered to be giving evidence of statesmanlike
endowment—sagacity, patience, good temper, political
realism.
War is not expected to be provoked from that quarter
of the great Far Eastern theater. Russia, for the time
being, is believed to be non-aggressive; the guess is
that her preoccupation with domestic development and
consolidation—not to mention possible ethical, legal, and
rationalistic restraints—holds her heavy hand. Japan,
at present, is conceived to be in a purely standpat posture, jealous of every foot of territory she has gained,
bent upon a Manchukuo and Jehol of her own choice,
steadfast for the dictum of the primacy of her responsibility for the peace of East Asia.
Well, if the short view of the world outlook, as it appears through Washington lenses, is not too disturbing,
how about the long? It is called a hopeless riddle, laughing alike at our knowledge, our philosophy and our
prophecy.
Future conditions, racial, national, moral, ratiocinative, are wholly indeterminable; we do not know what
races or nations will flourish or fail, what sort of morality and thinking will carry the day.
Conclusions? That each national sovereignty, America
particularly, from our point of view, must do the best
it can to promote its own well-being, and to be prepared

Experiments At Hopkins
The first indication of the existence
Of such a thing as heavy hydrogen

7 came as a result of Dr. Urey's experirnentation during his teaching at the
e.
Hopkins, but he first succeeded in isolating the element at the Bureau of
Standards in Washington. Since then
he has been working on it at Columbia, concentrating his efforts in spectroscopic analysis.
Heavy hydrogen differs from ordinary hydrogen in that it has a nucleus which has twice the normal
mass. It has an atomic weight of
two and a molecular weight of four,
although its valence is the normal
one.
Heavy Water Poisonous
Heavy water, a compound of oxygen
and heavy hydrogen, has been studied intensively, and has been found
to be poisonous to many forms of life
When present in large amounts;
strangely enough, it stimulates the
growth of plants when given in small
"doses." It has been found to exist
III very small amounts in almost all
water, but it is quite difficult to isolate. The isolation process consists
Of electrolyzing water, collecting the
heavy hydrogen which is set free after the normal hydrogen, and recombining it with oxygen.

In order to strengthen the Debating team for intercollegiate competalon, Dr. Lyons appointed men from
the squad to uphold each case in a
debate that was held last Friday, November 16. The affirmative case was
taken by Potter, Garfunkel, and Willen, while Morrow, Grossman, Ind
Sfekas defended the negative.
The question debated was: "Resolved: That the nations shall agree
to prevent the international shipment
of arms and munitions." The discussion centered around whether or not
the present system of manufacture
and sale of munitions is grave enough
to warrant this agreement, how this
is to be accomplished, and whether or
not this plan will abolish the evils of
the present system.
Rapid Progress Made
The team has made rapid progress
due to the energy with which members are working. Sylvan Garfunkel,
secretary of the club, has received by
request a large number of pamphlets
from the various government authorities on munitions. This material has
been placed on reserve in the main
library for the use of members of
the team.
In spite of the current propaganda
in regard to munitions makers resulting from the Senate investigation, it
appears that the negative had a
strong case.
The team which will represent the
Hopkins in the coming intercollegiate
debates will assume the affirmative
side.

An associate in chemistry at the
Ropkins from 1924-29, the Nobel
Laureate was appointed an associate
Professor at Columbia University in
1929, a position which he held until
bis appointment to a full professorship in 1934.
Awarded Gibbs Medal
He was awarded the Willard Gibbs
Medal in Chemistry by the Chicago
section of the American Chemical Society in 1934. Among the associations
of which he is a member are the
American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American
Chemical Society, the American Physical Society, the Society of Sigma Xi,
national honorary research fraternity,
and phi Lambda Upsilon, honorary
chemical fraternity.
1-le is the author of Atoms, Molecules and Guanta, a contributor to
• Treatise on Physical Chemistry
and was appointed editor of the Journal of Chemical Physics in 1933.

Thomas Ellis was elected president
of the Freshman Class in the final
elections held last Friday in Latrobe
Hall. The other officers of the class
elected at that time are Melville
Locker, vice-president; Marvin Kolker, secretary; Allan Pinkerton,
treasurer; Stanley Prager, sergeantat-arms; and Everett Gaunt, Student
Council representative.
These results were announced by
members of the Student Council after
the final elections, previous to which
there had been held nominations and
primary elections on Wednesday and
Thursday, to narrow down the extremely large field of candidates.

It all started when several St.
John's boys came over to Baltimore
and proceeded to paint the town red
with particular reference to the Hopkins campus. The police department,
however, always on the job, caught
them red-handed, and they were arrested, duly tried, and sentenced to
clean the paint that they had splattered all over the place.
They cleaned the campus, and went
back to Annapolis, but they were
highly indignant—so would you be in
their predicament—so when Benjamin Arnstein sallied forth from the
dorms to mail a letter, he disappeared in thin air.

fraternity.
Pinkerton is another student enrolled in the College of Arts and Sciences, who comes from Pennsylvania.
He serves on the varsity football

Business Student
The only Business Economics student to be elected to an office is
Prager, who hails from New York.
He is a candidate for the Barnstormers and has been cast in their forthcoming production. He is also a Phi
Alpha pledgee.
From far-off Indiana comes Everett Gaunt, who is enrolled in the College of Arts and Sciences.
Both Ellis and Gaunt have come
to the Hopkins holders of scholarships.

Frosh Commission
Discuss Fraternities
Two lively discussions, one on the
personal experiences of members with
regard to fraternities and the other
concerning the effects of alcoholic
beverage, featured last Thursday's
meeting of the Freshman Commission. The meeting was held at 6 p. m.
in Levering Hall.
Supper for the
members preceded the discussions.
To become a member of the Commission, the purpose of which is to
discuss freshman affairs, one must
be nominated by a regular member.
The three officers carefully consider
him, and if they find him acceptable,
he is placed on the roll.

Students Battle Policemen
With Tear Gas Bombs;
Firemen Put Out Bonfire
Tear gas bombs, flat tires on a police car, a light skirmish between
firemen and students, a stolen lantern;
all this was the result of the greatest display of "school spirit" shown
at the Johns Hopkins in a long time,
Although the night was Junior Rally night, the entire affair was dominated by the freshmen. The original
plan of the juniors was to make a
bonfire to arouse spirit for the JayJohnny game.
The students ransacked the stadium, the woods, and
alleys near the school to procure the
wood for the fire. The policemen let
the students build the fire, and it
roared at a merry rate.

The Last Luncheon?
WORD HAS reached us that the International Relations Club is wallowing in the depths of insecurity this
years as the direct result of an unprecedented penury
of members. The club is viewing the future with uncertainty, our outpost reports, and has decided to disband
unless a sharp pick-up is immediately effected within
its ranks. For this reason it has designated tomorrow's
luncheon meeting as the critical point in the determination of its continued existence. A satisfactory attendance
will enable it to persist and perhaps push forward; a
poor turn-out is to be considered indicative of lack of
student interest and will in all probability suffice for the
group's immediate and voluntary demise.
We are interested in the fate of this particular organization because it offers convincing evidence to a theory
which we have long held. This theory concerns those
students who actively scorn and score liberal and radical campus groups even to the point of egg baths, all
the while professing their preference and loyalty to the
status quo.
Yet, do they support that club which is peculiarly
ideal for their beliefs—namely, the conservative Relations Club, which is merely an informative discussion
group and takes no definite stand on current questions?
They do not, and, by that very token, denote that they
are not particularly interested or that they know all
about it already. The second inference is extremely
hazardous; the first allows just the least bit of suspicion to creep in concerning their real reason for perpetrating the disgrace of last April.
The Relations Club is prepared to give this conservative element a well-grounded basis on which to rest its
pretensions, so that it may counter with packs of facts
rather than lack of tact to the arguments advanced by
those with more radical leanings. This is the purpose
of its existence, and, as such, we heartily urge a good
measure of support at tomorrow's luncheon.

THIS Dr. Lynn Harold Hough is certainly a glutton for
punishment, make no mistake about that! If you question
the authority or authenticity of this statement, the
following explanation should swing you over:
Dr. Hough was one of the guests and principal speakers at the "Y" conference held at Eagles Mere last summer. Now Eagles Mere is a beautiful place, conducive
to practically every conceivable comfort. Dr. Hough
must have accepted the invitation to attend firm in the
conviction that he would lecture ever so occasionally
between hikes and blissful slumber. Or perhaps he contemplated writing another book 'neath the sylvan
friendliness of the environs.
Poor man, little did he reckon with a bunch of inquisitive imps who hailed from the Hopkins and who
evidently were crusading adherents of Veritas vos liberabit. For from the moment of his arrival to the time
when he tottered from the scene of action a sadder, yet
wider, clergyman, he was constantly pestered, peppered,
and finally sequestered by the murderous barrage of
questions put to him by these pitiless, insolent scamps.
The editor recalls one night in particular when he and
several others inveigled Dr. Hough into their room at
9.30 p. m. and hammered away until it was mutually
agreed to interrupt at 2 o'clock in conformity with an
alleged NRA code for religion!!
Don't think for a moment, however, that Dr. Hough
was revealed to disadvantage in these midsummer nightmares. If we had been unable to gain any satisfaction
from him at the outset, we would have dropped him
without further ado—we're quite independent, as you
notice. But the very nature of his replies led us on
ever gradually to follow him in his line of religious reasoning. At times we were forced to disagree violently,
upon other occasions we demurred; yet our impression
of the man was in no wise lessened by these frequent
clashes of opposing beliefs.
And so this week he has returned as guest of the
Hopkins Y. M. C. A. upon the occasion of its golden anniversary. He is to speak at tonight's Supper Club and
will also address the assembly on Thursday. But between these two public appearances, we can't censure
him if he goes into hibernation—experience should have
taught him that he can expect to find little Christian

Now as to Washington's way of thinking, on the basis
of the facts it has, concerning the probabilities in East
Asia, that vast testing-ground of the multitudinous nonaggressive Chinese, the restless, warm-water-seeking
Slays, and the short, sturdy, dour, death-scorning, expanding Japanese. There, too, barring the chapter of
accidents, Washington regards peace as at least temporarily more likely than war. The Nanking Government
is considered to be giving evidence of statesmanlike
endowment—sagacity, patience, good temper, political
realism.
War is not expected to be provoked from that quarter
of the great Far Eastern theater. Russia, for the time
being, is believed to be non-aggressive; the guess is
that her preoccupation with domestic development and
consolidation—not to mention possible ethical, legal, and
rationalistic restraints—holds her heavy hand. Japan,
at present, is conceived to be in a purely standpat posture, jealous of every foot of territory she has gained,
bent upon a Manchukuo and Jehol of her own choice,
steadfast for the dictum of the primacy of her responsibility for the peace of East Asia.
Well, if the short view of the world outlook, as it appears through Washington lenses, is not too disturbing,
how about the long? It is called a hopeless riddle, laughing alike at our knowledge, our philosophy and our
prophecy.
Future conditions, racial, national, moral, ratiocinative, are wholly indeterminable; we do not know what
races or nations will flourish or fail, what sort of morality and thinking will carry the day.

particularly, from our point of view, must do the best
it can to promote its own well-being, and to be prepared

Heavy hydrogen differs from ordinary hydrogen in that it has a nucleus which has twice the normal
mass. It has an atomic weight of
two and a molecular weight of four,

one.
Heavy Water Poisonous
Heavy water, a compound of oxygen
and heavy hydrogen, has been studied intensively, and has been found
to be poisonous to many forms of life
When present in large amounts;
strangely enough, it stimulates the
growth of plants when given in small
"doses." It has been found to exist
III very small amounts in almost all
water, but it is quite difficult to isolate. The isolation process consists
Of electrolyzing water, collecting the
heavy hydrogen which is set free after the normal hydrogen, and recombining it with oxygen.

In order to strengthen the Debating team for intercollegiate competalon, Dr. Lyons appointed men from
the squad to uphold each case in a
debate that was held last Friday, November 16. The affirmative case was
taken by Potter, Garfunkel, and Willen, while Morrow, Grossman, Ind
Sfekas defended the negative.
The question debated was: "Resolved: That the nations shall agree
to prevent the international shipment
of arms and munitions." The discussion centered around whether or not
the present system of manufacture
and sale of munitions is grave enough
to warrant this agreement, how this
is to be accomplished, and whether or
not this plan will abolish the evils of
the present system.
Rapid Progress Made
The team has made rapid progress
due to the energy with which members are working. Sylvan Garfunkel,
secretary of the club, has received by
request a large number of pamphlets
from the various government authorities on munitions. This material has
been placed on reserve in the main
library for the use of members of
the team.
In spite of the current propaganda
in regard to munitions makers resulting from the Senate investigation, it
appears that the negative had a
strong case.
The team which will represent the
Hopkins in the coming intercollegiate
debates will assume the affirmative
side.
